image.altText: Man in blue shirt wearing a necklace in front of a tree

items.synopsis: The family of a three-year-old who died in the remote community of Ngukurr say they took him to the local health clinic numerous times for treatment but were not transferred to a hospital.

title.children: 3yo's death the 'last straw' for community demanding government intervention in health clinic

image.altText: A carpenter drinks water on a construction site.

items.synopsis: Those working outdoors in the Northern Territory are forced to contend with extreme heat. Now scientists have looked to 2070 to see how the changing climate will impact the workforce.

title.children: The Northern Territory is getting hotter. Here's how harsher conditions could 'impair' the workforce

image.altText: Nusantara presentation in Singapore

items.synopsis: Joko Widodo heads home from Sydney with a promise of more assistance from Australia towards his legacy plan of building a new capital city on the island of Borneo.

title.children: Indonesia's 'clean, green, high-tech' new capital city is proving hard to sell to private investors around the world

image.altText: Philip Lowe sitting at a desk behind a microphone mid-sentence, gesturing with his right hand and looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Australian home borrowers are experiencing much, much more interest rate pain than borrowers in New Zealand, Canada, the UK or US – for one simple reason, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: The simple reason why Australian mortgage borrowers are in more pain than those in other countries

image.altText: woman standing looking down barrel holding baby boy, she has brown hair and is wearing glasses, baby has big blue eyes

items.synopsis: Home owners are struggling with increasing repayments amid reports that regional house prices have stagnated, despite interest rates staying on hold on Tuesday.

title.children: 'We've gone backwards': Young family sells home because they can't afford repayments, interest rate pause no help

image.altText: A woman smiles as her two small children sit at the top of a slide.

items.synopsis: Numerous studies show universal early childhood education provides a huge boost to the economy. The federal government is currently determining whether it will be introduced in Australia.

title.children: Studies show universal child care would result in sizeable boost to Australia's economy. So why don't we have it?

image.altText: An illustration of artists JK-47, Alex Lahey and Sarah Blasko

items.synopsis: More than 840 cover songs have been played in the triple j studios across 20 years. The data shows us how artists craft a cover song.

title.children: Some of the world's biggest songs are covers. What makes a good one?

image.altText: Two professional cricket players speak to each other on a pitch.

items.synopsis: English cricketers bristle at suggestions they have had a "Bazbawl" over the second Test, as former captain Joe Root says any suggestion Jonny Bairstow has tried for the same stumping as Alex Carey is incorrect.

title.children: Root attacks Australia, as Head claims Bairstow threatened to attempt identical dismisal

image.altText: Jake sits in a chair while receiving treatment

items.synopsis: Jake Usher wants you to talk about poo, and not for frivolous reasons. Last year, at the age of 31, he was diagnosed with stage 4 bowel cancer.

title.children: Jake thought bowel cancer was an old person's disease — until he was diagnosed

image.altText: A paracyclist turns the pedals of his bike with his hands during a race.

items.synopsis: US para-cyclist David Berling files a lawsuit against the International Paralympic Committee in a bid to help athletes address what he says is widespread cheating across the movement.

title.children: Para-cyclist files lawsuit in bid to stamp out widespread classification concerns

image.altText: The outline of a woman, obscured, in front of a sign for Mindil Beach

items.synopsis: A coroner hears several pieces of evidence against a man who beat his wife to death were ruled inadmissible before he pleaded guilty to a downgraded charge of manslaughter, having previously been charged with murder.

title.children: 'Defective' evidence against killer ruled inadmissible before charge downgraded, DV inquest hears

image.altText: A composite of Ash Barty and her newborn baby.

items.synopsis: Former world number one tennis player Ash Barty announces the birth of her first child, Hayden.

title.children: 'Our beautiful boy': Australian tennis great Ash Barty gives birth to son

image.altText: dog digging

items.synopsis: They're our furry, four-legged best friends, but dogs — like all pets — come with their challenges. We asked for your curly questions on canine ownership and you sent through hundreds. Here are some of the more common experiences, and our experts' advice.

title.children: You sent our experts hundreds of questions on dog behaviour. Here's what we learnt

image.altText: Against a dark background, an older woman is seen from behind turning her face to the side, with serious expression.

items.synopsis: With reports of elder abuse on the rise in Australia, these women in their 80s are sharing their stories in the hope that others seek the help they need.

title.children: The small acts of violence that led 81-year-old Francene to understand she was experiencing elder abuse

image.altText: Warwick Thornton and Cate Blanchett sit smiling.

items.synopsis: Hollywood star Cate Blanchett says this year's referendum on constitutional recognition and a Voice to Parliament represents "an incredible opportunity" for Australia to embrace its history.

title.children: 'Incredible opportunity': Cate Blanchett and Warwick Thornton on the Voice referendum

image.altText: 'Walk together to a better future': Linda Burney responds to the Liberal Party's opposition to the Voice

items.synopsis: Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney will name four priorities for the proposed Voice to Parliament in a speech to the National Press Club today, after growing pressure to detail how it would benefit First Nations people.

title.children: Linda Burney says gaps in health and education are among key priorities for the Voice

image.altText: Twitter logo and a photo of Elon Musk are displayed through magnifier in an illustration.

items.synopsis: Twitter defends its decision to limit the number of tweets that users can read and the Australian dollar rises to 67 US cents. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Twitter defends cap on reading tweets, global stocks drift,  Australian dollar rises to 67 US cents

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank kept interest rates on hold yesterday at an 11 year high of 4.1 per cent, but economists are warning that further rate rises could cause a recession in Australia. RBA governor Philip Lowe signalled in his post meeting statement that more rate hikes may be needed to bring inflation under control. The ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan has been speaking to Deloitte Access Economics partner Stephen Smith who says a recession can't be ruled out.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rate hikes could tip Australia into recession

children.content: The Reserve Bank kept interest rates on hold yesterday at an 11 year high of 4.1 per cent, but economists are warning that further rate rises could cause a recession in Australia.
RBA governor Philip Lowe signalled in his post meeting statement that more rate hikes may be needed to bring inflation under control.
The ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan has been speaking to Deloitte Access Economics partner Stephen Smith who says a recession can't be ruled out.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: On the weekend, Twitter boss Elon Musk announced another unpopular move by placing a temporary limit on how many tweets that users can read in a day. Overnight, Twitter chief executive Linda Yaccarino defended the move saying it was an action to strengthen the platform. "When you have a mission like Twitter you need to make big moves to keep strengthening the platform", Ms Yaccarino tweeted. In a blog post, Twitter said only a small percentage of people have been affected by the limits, which were put in place to "detect and eliminate bots and other bad actors." "To ensure the authenticity of our user base we must take extreme measures to remove spam and bots from our platform." "That's why we temporarily limited usage so we could detect and eliminate bots and other bad actors from harming the platform." Twitter said it was working to prevent accounts from scraping people's public Twitter data to build AI models and manipulating people and conversation on the the platform. "Currently the restrictions affect a small percentage of people using the platform, and we will provide an update when the work is complete." "As it relates to our customers, effects on advertising have been minimal." Here's more on the reading limits from Velvet Winter.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Twitter defends reading caps

featuredLink.title: Elon Musk announces limit for how many posts users can read on Twitter

children.content: On the weekend, Twitter boss Elon Musk announced another unpopular move by placing a temporary limit on how many tweets that users can read in a day.
Overnight, Twitter chief executive Linda Yaccarino defended the move saying it was an action to strengthen the platform.
"When you have a mission like Twitter you need to make big moves to keep strengthening the platform", Ms Yaccarino tweeted.
In a blog post, Twitter said only a small percentage of people have been affected by the limits, which were put in place to "detect and eliminate bots and other bad actors."
"To ensure the authenticity of our user base we must take extreme measures to remove spam and bots from our platform."
"That's why we temporarily limited usage so we could detect and eliminate bots and other bad actors from harming the platform."
Twitter said it was working to prevent accounts from scraping people's public Twitter data to build AI models and manipulating people and conversation on the the platform.
"Currently the restrictions affect a small percentage of people using the platform, and we will provide an update when the work is complete."
"As it relates to our customers, effects on advertising have been minimal."
Here's more on the reading limits from Velvet Winter.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning and welcome to the ABC Market's blog. Global stocks were little changed overnight with the US market closed for the July 4 holiday. The ASX SPI 200 is down slightly, indicating the Australian share market will open lower today. The FTSE 100 in London lost ground, while the Euro Stoxx 600 share index put on 0.1 per cent. Oil prices increased as Saudi Arabia and Russia extended their production cuts. And the Australian dollar has risen overnight to around 67 US cents, a day after the Reserve Bank kept official interest rates on hold. Join me today for the latest markets news.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to open lower, Australian dollar rises to 67 US cents

children.content: Good morning and welcome to the ABC Market's blog.
Global stocks were little changed overnight with the US market closed for the July 4 holiday.
The ASX SPI 200 is down slightly, indicating the Australian share market will open lower today.
The FTSE 100 in London lost ground, while the Euro Stoxx 600 share index put on 0.1 per cent.
Oil prices increased as Saudi Arabia and Russia extended their production cuts.
And the Australian dollar has risen overnight to around 67 US cents, a day after the Reserve Bank kept official interest rates on hold.
Join me today for the latest markets news.

image.altText: A close up of a smiling woman wearing a traditional dress on a Bhutanese square.

items.synopsis: After centuries of isolation, Bhutan opened its doors to tourism in the 1970s. But when the ABC was granted rare entry into the country, it found a nation losing a high proportion of people — mainly to Australia.

title.children: 'It feels so empty': The forbidden kingdom of Bhutan is turning into a ghost town

image.altText: a graphic of a middle aged man with a comissioner at lecturn behind him, and two women

items.synopsis: Robodebt was ruled a massive public administration failure and a shameful chapter in Australia's history by the Federal Court. A royal commission is about to make a ruling on who was responsible.

title.children: How was Robodebt allowed to happen? We're about to find out

image.altText: Britain's Kate, Princess of Wales, left, stands in the royal box with tennis champion Roger Federer and his wife Mirka.

items.synopsis: The Princess of Wales is among Wimbledon spectators giving Roger Federer a standing ovation of almost 2 minutes as the retired tennis star enters the Royal Box on Centre Court.

title.children: 'Inspiration, icon, legend': Wimbledon farewells Federer with tribute and standing ovation

image.altText: Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak walking out of Number 10 Downing Street

items.synopsis: An assessment of new evidence leads British police to reopen an investigation into COVID-19 lockdown breaches at a December 2020 event held in the headquarters of the governing Conservative Party.

title.children: London police reopen investigation into COVID lockdown party

image.altText: A woman with brown curly hair in a business suit standing outside a grey building with columns

items.synopsis: South Australia's parliament still has a "toxic" culture of bullying and harassment, according to SA Best MLC Connie Bonaros, despite a raft of changes designed to overhaul the workplace.

title.children: 'I have people reaching out to me for help': Female MP says culture of SA parliament still 'toxic'

image.altText: Rowena Sweeney, Tasmania

items.synopsis: Rowena admits it was a TV ad that convinced her to buy funeral insurance. She'd be happy with a "no-frills" send-off but says she feels trapped in the arrangement, which will see her pay $40,000 by the time she's 90.

title.children: 'Trapped until I am 90': Rowena will pay tens of thousands of dollars in funeral insurance to protect her only asset

image.altText: tanya pliberseK

items.synopsis: The federal water minister says the plan is "too far behind" and has requested advice on whether its water-recovery targets can be achieved by the legislated June 2024 deadline.

title.children: Tanya Plibersek says 'course correction' required for off-track Murray-Darling Basin Plan

image.altText: A woman in a flannelette shirt with a house on stilts in the background

items.synopsis: Residents from South Lismore were devastated by floods in 2022 but are struggling to access the scheme that offered them a chance of escape. Now they're being told the council wants to put a stop to residential development because of the flood risk.

title.children: People are being told their flooded homes are not high-risk. The council begs to differ

image.altText: A blonde woman sits in front of a microphone and looks up with a serious expression, wearing a floral blouse

items.synopsis: A Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman has called the attack, which disrupted flight operations at Moscow's major airport, "yet another act of terrorism".

title.children: 'Act of terrorism': Russia accuses Ukraine of another drone attack on Moscow

image.altText: Lots of small children walking to class.

items.synopsis: Parents have created schools to cater to their own religious and philosophical beliefs, or to focus on the particular needs of their children and communities, write Nigel Howard and Andrew Bills.

title.children: These parents weren't happy so they started their own school — and they're part of a long tradition

image.altText: a lady sits on a bench with a man and a small girl smiling at a camera

items.synopsis: Bendigo mum Brooke Lee wants to see her daughter go to school and get married. A new clinical trial may help make that possible.

title.children: Australian-first cancer drug trial offers hope to patients with incurable lymphoma

image.altText: A woman covered in blue paint speaks on the phone on a hospital bed.

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin will be briefed about the beating of a Russian journalist and lawyer in Chechnya, the Kremlin said, describing a serious attack that required an energetic response.

title.children: 'Gun to my head': Russian reporter kidnapped in Chechnya, with Putin to be briefed

image.altText: A man dressed in fire gear watches an burnt and smoky horizon near sunset.

items.synopsis: The World Meteorological Organization has declared the first El Niño eight years after the last weather event developed, bringing record-high temperatures.

title.children: High global temperatures and disruptive weather likely as international weather agency declares El Niño

image.altText: A Palestinian holds a flag in front of a fire.

items.synopsis: Israel is close to completing its raid in Jenin, after the fiercest fighting in the flashpoint West Bank town in more than two decades, which has left 12 Palestinians dead and forced thousands to flee.

title.children: Israeli forces begin to withdraw from Jenin after 12 Palestinians killed, as Tel Aviv stabbing rampage leaves eight injured

image.altText: A young man and woman standing together in front of a light plane.

items.synopsis: A transport safety investigation into a plane crash that killed a newlywed couple and their unborn child in North Queensland earlier this year finds that the pilot had completed the practical requirements to obtain a licence but not the flight or theory tests.

title.children: Investigation finds pilot was unlicensed during fatal plane crash that killed young couple in poor weather

image.altText: The police divers boat at the Rockhampton boat ramp

items.synopsis: Thieves allegedly broke into the Victorian family's caravan, stole their car keys, went on a joy-ride through Rockhampton, then dumped their vehicle in the Fitzroy River.

title.children: Police divers to retrieve $300k vehicle dumped among 'the crocodiles' after alleged theft from holiday makers

image.altText: A person takes a photo as a full moon known as the "Buck Moon" rises behind the Temple of Poseidon, in Cape Sounion, near Athens

items.synopsis: Don't stress if the cloudy weather locked you out of last night's supermoon — there's three more before the end of the year.

title.children: Clouds blocked the buck supermoon for many in Australia, so here are photos of it from around the world
